information.title: Introduction
information.description: The Anti-Defection Law was enacted in 1985 through the 52nd Amendment to the Constitution, adding the Tenth Schedule. It aims to combat 'the evil of political defections'.

information.title: Grounds for Disqualification
information.description: A member can be disqualified if they voluntarily give up party membership, vote against party directions, or abstain from voting contrary to party instructions (unless condoned within 15 days).

information.title: Exceptions
information.description: The law allows a party to merge with or into another party provided that at least two-thirds of its legislators are in favor of the merger. In such a scenario, neither the members who've chosen to merge, nor the ones who stay with the original party will face disqualification.

information.title: Speaker's/Chairman's Role
information.description: The decision on questions of disqualification on ground of defection is referred to the Chairman or the Speaker of the House, and their decision is final.

information.title: Judicial Review
information.description: The Supreme Court has held that the decision of the Speaker/Chairman is subject to judicial review, though the scope of such review is limited.

information.title: Time Limit
information.description: The Supreme Court in 2020 ruled that Speakers should decide on disqualification petitions within a reasonable period, generally considered to be three months.

information.title: Criticism
information.description: The law has been criticized for potentially curtailing the freedom of speech of legislators and for giving too much power to party leaders.

information.title: 91st Amendment Act, 2003
information.description: This amendment strengthened the anti-defection law by deleting an exception provision which allowed splits if 1/3rd of legislators of a party defected.
